causes: Trade imbalances between China and Britain
British demand for Chinese tea, silk, and porcelain
Introduction of opium by British merchants to China
events_leading_up_to_war: Destruction of opium stocks by Chinese authorities
British military response to protect their trade interests

result.territorial_changes: Hong Kong Island ceded to the United Kingdom

major_battles.name: Battle of Canton
major_battles.description: British forces captured the city of Canton (Guangzhou) after heavy fighting.

major_battles.name: Battle of the Bogue
major_battles.description: British forces defeated Chinese defenses at the Bocca Tigris forts.

major_battles.name: Battle of Chinkiang
major_battles.description: British forces captured the city of Chinkiang (Zhenjiang), opening the way to Nanking (Nanjing).

terms: Cession of Hong Kong Island to the UK
Opening of five treaty ports (Canton, Amoy, Foochow, Ningpo, and Shanghai) for international trade
Extraterritorial rights for British citizens in China
Indemnity payment of 21 million silver dollars to Britain
impact: Marked the beginning of the 'Century of Humiliation' for China
Set a precedent for other Western powers to seek similar concessions from China

long_term_effects: Rise of anti-foreign sentiment in China
Eventual lead up to the Second Opium War

economic: Increased British economic influence in Asia
political: Established British dominance in the region
Exposed weaknesses in Qing Dynasty governance
social: Widespread addiction to opium in China
Cultural exchanges between East and West
